detail.abstract:
The Public Procurement Law Review (Sweet & Maxwell / UK) has published a special issue focused on international trade and procurement. Four of the pieces from the special issue, discussed below, are available in the attached.

In their introductory editorial, “Procurement Trade Agreements and Their Discontents,” Robert Anderson (Honorary Professor at the University of Nottingham School of Law, and Senior Fellow, Competition and Innovation Lab, The George Washington University, and former team lead at the WTO on the Government Procurement Agreement) and Christopher Yukins (GW Law) put the accompanying articles into context. They noted that the GPA, as the premier trade agreement, “is currently under an unprecedented degree of scrutiny on the part of one of its founding Parties, . . . the United States,” which calls for a “spirited defence . . . of the GPA and other trade agreements embodying government procurement commitments and their contribution to international governance and prosperity.”

In her piece, “Expansion of International Procurement Commitments: WTO Procurement Agreement Versus Free Trade Agreements,” Jean Heilman Grier (Djaghe, LLC), argued that the large numbers of nations that have committed to open their government markets to foreign suppliers “reflects the important role that government procurement plays in international trade.” She noted that while “the GPA will continue to add new members—albeit slowly, [free trade agreements (FTAs)] will provide the principal expansion of international procurement commitments, as they encompass both GPA parties and those outside the plurilateral agreement.” Although the GPA’s membership “may be outpaced by FTAs” which she described in detail, Jean Grier wrote that the GPA “will continue to serve as the international gold standard for government procurement provisions and the foundation for procurement rules across the globe.” She cautioned, though, that the “potential spoiler is the United States with President Trump’s America First trade policy undermining existing agreements and threatening withdrawal from the GPA and even the WTO.”

In their piece on bid protests and the trade agreements, “The GPA’s Domestic Review Procedures Through the Lens of North American Sub-Central Implementation: Flexibility or Incoherence?,” Derek McKee (Faculté de droit, Université de Montréal) and Daniel Schoeni (University of Dayton) noted that although the GPA “requires parties to give foreign suppliers access to independent and impartial fora where they can challenge public procurement decisions,” many U.S. states and Canadian provinces — though both countries are members of the GPA “have domestic review procedures that comply with some, but not all,” of the GPA’s requirements. They place part of the blame on ambiguities in Article XVIII of the GPA, and provide examples of North American sub-central review systems that embody these ambiguities.

The final piece, “An Empirical Study of Bid Protests by Disappointed Tenderers in US States,” by Daniel Schoeni (University of Dayton), was an extension of Professor Schoeni’s doctoral research at the University of Nottingham. In it, he reported on data he gathered on bid protests (challenges) in the states, and noted that bid protests are “at least as common at the state level as at the federal level.” Knowing that — that protests are a commonly available remedy for uncompetitive discrimination at the state level — could, Professor Schoeni noted, “foster confidence among foreign suppliers and thus encourage greater participation from abroad.”

This extract containing an editorial and three articles was first published by Thomson Reuters in the Public Procurement Law Review at the citation noted, and is reproduced with permission of the publishers.

detail.title: Flow-Constrained Risk Management for Operational Technology Security: A Multi-Criteria Framework for Critical Infrastructure

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

detail.abstract: Critical infrastructure operators face unprecedented cybersecurity threats whilst operating under severe resource constraints that traditional security frameworks fail to address. This research presents a novel flow-constrained risk management framework that enables systematic improvement of operational technology security within realistic organisational limitations. Building on lean manufacturing optimisation principles, the framework constrains security improvements through work-in-progress limitations: exactly one major improvement per quarter per asset, plus a maximum of three minor improvements in parallel. The approach integrates progressive Annual Loss Exposure refinement with multi-criteria stakeholder decision-making to provide measurable progress without requiring lengthy strategic investment cycles. The framework addresses four critical implementation gaps: systematic underestimation of resource constraints, reliance on non-existent representative datasets, insufficient recognition of behavioural biases, and dependence on strategic approval processes mismatched to threat response timelines. Mathematical analysis examines the convergence properties of the progressive risk assessment methodology, whilst queuing theory validates the efficiency improvements of the flow-constrained approach. Implementation feasibility was demonstrated within a global conglomerate operating across energy, mining, and manufacturing sectors. The framework provides the theoretical foundation for achieving systematic security enhancement within practical constraints, enabling board-level visibility through consistent risk reduction trends whilst avoiding contentious resource allocation debates.

publicationDetails.detailsText: This paper is forthcoming in Texas L. Rev. Vol. 104

detail.abstract: This paper will discuss and analyze the litigation in response to the Trump administration's imposition of tariffs, brought under the questionable authority of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). 1 Rather than using traditional tariff authorities like Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act and Section 301 of the Trade Act, the Trump administration used the IEEPA as statutory authority for these sweeping tariffs due to its lack of lengthy procedural hurdles. Though these IEEPA tariffs went to immediate effect, the legal questions surrounding Trump's choice of authority have abounded. The history of the statute, the history of tariff litigation, and the Supreme Court's major questions doctrine all contribute to the foregoing analysis of whether this broad emergency action was actually legal. Following a review of the most relevant legal arguments, this paper turns to the body that has made the legal waters surrounding tariff imposition murky: Congress and their widespread delegation of their enumerated powers.

detail.abstract: Introduction: Table-Column-Row (TCR) as a Digital Right CitizenssApp is a platform built entirely on the Table-Column-Row (TCR) modelthe same intuitive format found in everything from paper ledgers to spreadsheets. The idea is simple but powerful: if a person can draw a table with rows and columns, they should be able to create and use software. In the analog world, every citizen could record information with pen and paper; in the digital world, that same simplicity should exist[1]. CitizenssApp treats basic data operations (CRUD-Create, Read, Update, Delete) as a fundamental digital right rather than a complex programming task. "Digital empowerment is no longer a privilege-it is a fundamental need for every citizen. CRUD is the new pen and paper."[2] The platform's vision is to democratize software creation by removing cost, complexity, and dependency, much like how universal literacy made reading/writing accessible to all[3][4]. Lack of access to simple app functionality today creates digital exclusion[5], so CitizenssApp frames basic software literacy as a necessity, empowering individuals and communities to build their own solutions.

AI.practical_contributions: 提供了一个易于使用的平台，帮助个人和社区自主构建解决方案，减少数字排斥。

title: The Experience Link: Why Payments are the Final Frontier When Shopping Online
affiliations: ESCP Business School

detail.title: The Experience Link: Why Payments are the Final Frontier When Shopping Online
detail.abstract: In digital commerce, payment methods are more than functional tools—they shape customer experience and influence purchasing behavior. The necessity to pay for products and services online initiated the shift from cash-based to electronic-based business transactions. Yet, existing research primarily focuses on adoption and technology rather than the experiential and strategic dimensions of payments. This paper uses the Experience Value Matrix (EVM), which integrates Pine and Gilmore's four realms of experience with an adoption of Woodruff's dynamic customer value framework to position payment methods not just by usage but by experience. Based on panel data from Germany and the Netherlands, the study reveals that few dominant payment methods shape over 90% of online transactions, with large variances in experience perception. The findings offer strategic guidance for wallet providers and merchants on how to align payment experiences with brand promises, pricing models, and consumer expectations. This paper takes the position that more and more payment methods are omni-channel ready (available both online and offline) and that the actual positioning of the payment method and related pricing allows for further differentiation from an experience perspective. The EVM framework invites managers to reframe payments as strategic assets that drive both customer satisfaction and business growth. By linking value perception with experience design, businesses can position payments as a final frontier in customer experience innovation.

detail.abstract: Accurate early-stage prediction of customers' purchase behavior of high-involvement products is critical for optimizing resource allocation and guiding strategic sales decisions. While voice interactions serve as a rich source of behavioral signals during early customer engagement, their unstructured and multimodal nature presents significant analytical challenges. This study introduces CogniAffect Dual-Involvement Prediction (CADIP), a novel, theory-driven approach for forecasting customer purchase decisions based on voice interaction data. Grounded in involvement theory, CADIP identifies and models two latent behavioral dimensions embedded in voice interactions: cognitive engagement and affective arousal. CADIP leverages the multimodal capabilities of large language models and large speech models to extract both linguistic and acoustic features. It captures cognitive engagement through an attention mechanism that treats proactive inquiries as contextual queries, and it detects arousal expression via a dedicated arousal-gating module that dynamically modulate vocal cues to reflect affective intensity. Together, these mechanisms form a dual-pathway architecture designed to detect nuanced signals of customer involvement from early-stage dialogues. We evaluate CADIP using real-world automotive sales call data and show that it significantly outperforms state-of-the-art benchmarks in identifying high-potential customers at the early decision stage. Ablation analyses further demonstrate the value of combining cognitive and affective signals, as well as the benefits of cross-modal integration. Beyond its methodological contributions to voice analytics, deployment simulations suggest substantial managerial benefits: a 51.8% reduction in sales representatives' workload and an 80% increase in conversion rates. This research contributes to the information systems literature by introducing CADIP, a multimodal, theory-guided IT artifact that operationalizes psychological constructs from customer behavior in a predictive framework. It also advances the design of intelligent sales management systems by extracting long-horizon insights from unstructured early-stage voice data.

title: A Dilemma to Address: Striking a Fair Balance Between The Right to be Forgotten and The Right of Freedom of Expression and Information in European Law Context

detail.title: A Dilemma to Address: Striking a Fair Balance Between The Right to be Forgotten and The Right of Freedom of Expression and Information in European Law Context
detail.abstract: In today's world, the internet has become an indispensable mean for sharing and receiving information worldwide. People from all over the world can access information and news on any topic simultaneously, in a matter of seconds, and share their opinions on any subject, without any restrictions. At first glance, this underlines the importance of freedom of expression and information as a reflection of the digital age. Having said that, it doesn't always lead to positive outcomes for everyone, as it creates a crucial conflict between those who seek to access, share, and publish information and those who are part of the information and are exposed to its negative effects throughout their lives. People, who were unable to integrate into society due to being part of the negative information published about them on the internet permanently, needed a correction mechanism to rectify this and re-create their identity in the digital environment. This mechanism has been established as the “right to be forgotten” and regulated under European law in detail. Although this is a correction mechanism for people, who have been negatively affected by the information published on the internet about them, and despite the freedom of expression and information has been regulated as an exception to this right under European law, it’s indeed a compelling and complicated evaluation to decide which of these rights should prevail in each case. From this point of view, in this article, the right to be forgotten and the right of freedom of expression and information are evaluated under European law, and the conflict between them is addressed in light of the perspective developed by European law over the years, based on regulations and case law, in order to strike a fair balance.

detail.title: The Influence of Digital Leadership Styles on Consumer Trust and Brand Loyalty in the E-commerce Sector
detail.abstract: In the world of e-commerce, where rapid digital transformation is reshaping consumer interactions, this study investigates the impact of digital leadership styles on customer trust and brand loyalty. The study focuses on brand loyalty and trust. Digital leadership, defined as the use of technology to manage teams and influence customer relationships, is becoming increasingly vital for a company's success. This article examines three key leadership styles: transformational, transactional, and laissez-faire, as well as the impact each has on consumerbrand interactions.This study investigates how leadership actions affect consumer perceptions, satisfaction, and loyalty. It accomplishes this by doing a literature review, which is a synthesis of prior research on digital leadership in ecommerce. According to the findings, transformational leadership, which promotes innovation, vision, and personalized customer interaction, has the most positive impact on both trust and loyalty. On the other side, transactional and laissez-faire leadership styles have little, if any, impact. The study's findings highlight the need of employing transformational leadership strategies for ecommerce organizations seeking to improve customer interactions and ensure long-term brand loyalty.

title: "A Relationship Marketing Perspective on E-Banking Adoption: Evidence from Iranian Customers Using an Extended Tam"

detail.title: "A Relationship Marketing Perspective on E-Banking Adoption: Evidence from Iranian Customers Using an Extended Tam"
detail.abstract: As digital transformation accelerates within the banking sector, understanding the behavioral and marketing-related determinants of electronic banking (e-banking) adoption has become increasingly critical—especially in emerging economies. This study applies an extended Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) enriched with relationship marketing constructs (trust, satisfaction) and user experience (familiarity) to model e-banking adoption among customers of the Cooperative Development Bank in Iran. Results from PLS-SEM based on 379 responses reveal that customer satisfaction (β = 0.750) is the most influential driver of e-banking adoption. Findings highlight that perceived ease of use, usefulness, and trust contribute significantly to brand experience and customer loyalty. The study extends marketing theory by embedding digital trust and brand relationship into the TAM and provides practical implications for improving brand equity and loyalty through digital banking platforms.

title: AI-Powered vs. Manual Advertising: A Field Experiment in E-Commerce
affiliations: University of Florida - Warrington College of Business Administration, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Zhejiang Gongshang University and University of Florida - Warrington College of Business Administration

detail.title: AI-Powered vs. Manual Advertising: A Field Experiment in E-Commerce
detail.abstract: Although artificial intelligence has been proven successful in multiple business contexts, research on its effectiveness in advertising has been lacking. In this study, we collaborated with a major Chinese electronics company and conducted a field experiment on a leading e-commerce platform to assess the performance of AI-powered advertising vis-à-vis manual advertising in two stages of online shopping, the clicking (exploration) and purchasing (decision) stages. Manual advertising targets audiences through fixed demographic filters, while AI-powered advertising dynamically mines vast behavioral and real-time data to pinpoint the most likely buyers. Our study delivers several important and interesting results. Due to leveraging more demographic and behavioral data with superior computational power, we identify a selective conversion effect that AI-powered advertising may accurately target relevant consumers who possess more knowledge of products and exercise higher product certainty, which leads to a lower likelihood of clicking on products in the clicking stage but a higher chance of purchasing products in the purchasing stage after clicking. Likewise, we identify an augmentation of the AI-algorithm-induced selective conversion effect on popular products in both stages: consumers may possess more knowledge of and familiarity with popular products than niche products, and thus, may be less likely to click on popular products of enhanced clarity in the clicking stage; in the purchasing stage, the selective conversion effect on popular products may facilitate the decision-making process and achieve higher sales. In addition, we discover that the selective conversion effect of AI-powered advertising may manifest differently for innovative products: it weakens in the clicking stage, increasing consumer clicks due to curiosity and limited information on innovative products; however, the selective conversion effect strengthens in the following purchasing stage as consumers gain a higher quality perception of innovative products after clicking and entering the product pages, contributing to enhanced product certainty and more purchases. Our study offers several critical implications for sellers to develop product-specific advertising strategies and for platforms to design and improve advertising tools to sustainably collaborate with sellers.

title: Predicting Field Experiments with Large Language Models

detail.title: Predicting Field Experiments with Large Language Models
detail.abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated unprecedented emergent capabilities, including content generation, translation, and simulation of human behavior. Field experiments, on the other hand, are widely employed in social studies to examine real-world human behavior through carefully designed manipulations and treatments. However, field experiments are known to be expensive and time consuming. Therefore, an interesting question is whether and how LLMs can be utilized for field experiments. In this paper, we propose and evaluate an automated LLM-based framework to predict the outcomes of a field experiment. Applying this framework to 276 experiments about a wide range of human behaviors drawn from renowned economics literature yields a prediction accuracy of 78%. Moreover, we find that the distributions of the results are either bimodal or highly skewed. By investigating this abnormality further, we identify that field experiments related to complex social issues such as ethnicity, social norms, and ethical dilemmas can pose significant challenges to the prediction performance. detail.abstract: We study the relationship between investors’ social media activity and earnings announcement returns. To distinguish between information contained in peer-to-peer interaction and user-posted content, we analyze conversation networks on Reddit using centrality metrics from network science and classify user sentiment with large language models. We show that pre-announcement sentiment is positively associated with short-term cumulative abnormal returns only if it does not spark pre-announcement controversy. If pre-announcement controversy arises, we document a negative association. Our findings present a more nuanced view on the wisdom of crowds hypothesis, highlighting that peer-to-peer interaction on social media exhibits a pattern of normalization, and thus contains informational value beyond content.

detail.abstract: We examine the relationship between household incomes and the biodiversity footprints of consumption in the United States from 1996 to 2022. Combining detailed household expenditure surveys with environmentally-extended multi-regional input-output accounting methods, we calculate consumptionbased (i) land-use and (ii) species-loss footprints as proxies for overall biodiversity pressure. We find that the average biodiversity footprints of US households declined between 1996 and the early 2010s but began increasing again thereafter, as rising consumption pressure outpaced technological improvements. To characterize the relationship between household income and biodiversity footprints, we construct Environmental Engel Curves (EECs). Just like aggregate footprints, EECs shifted downwards until the early 2010s but have moved upwards in recent years, mainly due to a more biodiversity-intensive composition of expenditures, as we show. Moreover, EECs for land use are concave, implying a "biodiversity-equality trade-off" of moderate size. In 2022, full redistribution to achieve perfect income equality would have raised aggregate land use by 3.2% all else equal, calling for additional efforts to maintain a given biodiversity conservation goal.

detail.abstract: Economic and climate shocks inflict huge economic costs and undermine sustainable development (SD). This study is the first comprehensive attempt to empirically assess the influence of economic and climate resilience, which can mitigate those costs, on SD. Our analysis is based on a panel dataset of 31 countries from 2007 to 2021 and advanced econometric techniques, including panel-corrected standard errors, feasible generalized least squares, panel quantile regression, and local projections. Furthermore, dynamic analysis indicates that both types of resilience have persistent effects on SD and quantile analysis validates the robustness and consistency of our findings across different stages of development.

detail.title: Verba Volant, Transcripta Manent: What Corporate Earnings Calls Reveal About the AI Stock Rally
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the economic impact of technological innovation, focusing on generative AI (GenAI) following ChatGPT’s release in November 2022. We propose a novel framework leveraging large language models to analyze earnings call transcripts. Our method quantifies firms’ GenAI exposure and classifies sentiment as opportunity, adoption, or risk. Using panel econometric techniques, we assess GenAI exposure’s impact on S&P 500 firms’ financial performance over 2014-2023. We find two main results. First, GenAI exposure rose sharply after ChatGPT’s release, particularly in IT, Consumer Services, and Consumer Discretionary sectors, coinciding with sentiment shifts toward adoption. Second, GenAI exposure significantly influenced stock market performance. Firms with early and high GenAI exposure saw stronger returns, though earnings expectations improved modestly. Panel regressions show a 1 percentage point increase in GenAI exposure led to 0.26% rise in quarterly excess returns. Difference-in-Difference estimates indicate 2.4% average quarterly stock price increases following ChatGPT’s release.

detail.title: The Term Structure of Return Expectations
detail.abstract: Using a long-running survey of U.S. investors, we examine subjective return expectations for the aggregate stock market across horizons from one month to ten years. Short-term expectations are extrapolative, whereas forward return expectations are contrarian. The term structure of return expectations is upward-sloping in bad times and relatively flat in good times. We also find evidence of overreaction in return expectations. We introduce perceived mispricing as a complementary belief measure and show that it helps explain the dynamics of the term structure. Perceived underpricing is negatively correlated with short-term return expectations but strongly positively correlated with forward return expectations. It is also positively related to mutual fund inflows and stated investment decisions, and emerges as a significant consideration when investors, in free-text responses, explain the drivers of their trading intentions.

title: Market Luck: Skill-Biased Inequality and Redistributive Preferences

detail.title: Market Luck: Skill-Biased Inequality and Redistributive Preferences
detail.abstract: Market forces beyond individual control are a central driver of income inequality, a phenomenon we refer to as market luck. In meritocratic societies, this raises the question of whether individuals perceive such inequalities as fair. To address this question, we conduct experiments in the US, France, and China in which inequality between workers emerges due to random matching with buyers who require specific skills, creating inequality driven by market luck. Our findings from the US indicate that individuals are more accepting of inequalities resulting from market luck than those caused by brute luck, even though both are beyond workers' control and unrelated to their effort. The results are directionally consistent across all three countries, though with varying magnitudes of treatment effects, suggesting that redistributive preferences are sensitive to cultural differences and exposure to market institutions. We further validate our findings in survey experiments using more natural contexts and show that behavior in the experiments predicts support for real-world policies. Our results provide a novel explanation for the muted demand for redistribution amid rising inequality.

By combining perspectives from sustainable finance, digital finance, and emerging asset market participation, this study provides new evidence on how these capabilities interact to influence responsible investment choices in technology-driven financial markets.

AI.theory_contributions: 揭示了金融和数字能力如何协同作用，影响技术驱动金融市场中的负责任投资选择。
AI.practical_contributions: 为政策制定者和市场参与者提供了关于如何通过提升金融和数字素养促进可持续投资的新证据。

title: Influence and Connectivity in Networks: A Generating Function Approach
affiliations: Southwestern University of Finance and Economics (SWUFE), Tsinghua University - Tsinghua University School of Economics and Management and Tsinghua University - Tsinghua University School of Economics and Management

detail.title: Influence and Connectivity in Networks: A Generating Function Approach
detail.abstract: Many widely used network centralities are based on counting walks that meet specific criteria. This paper introduces a systematic framework for walk enumeration using generating functions. We introduce a first-passage decomposition that uniquely divides any walk passing through specified nodes or links into two components: a first-reaching walk and a subsequent walk. This decomposition yields a system of interconnected equations that relate three disjoint categories of walks: unrestricted walks, walks that avoid specific elements, and walks that pass through designated sets. The framework offers a range of applications, including evaluating the effects of structural interventions-such as node or link modifications-on network walks, generalizing target centrality to multi-receiver scenarios in information networks, and comparing different strategies for adding links.

AI.tldr: 本文提出了一种基于生成函数的系统性框架，用于网络中的路径枚举，通过首次通过分解将路径分为两部分，并建立了三类路径之间的关系。该框架可用于评估结构干预效果、推广目标中心性及比较链接策略。
AI.research_question: 如何通过生成函数和首次通过分解系统地枚举网络中满足特定条件的路径？
AI.motivation: 现有网络中心性方法基于路径计数，但缺乏系统性框架来统一处理路径枚举问题。
AI.theoretical_framework: 生成函数理论、首次通过分解、路径分类（无限制路径、避免特定元素的路径、通过指定集合的路径）。
AI.method: 提出基于生成函数的系统性框架，利用首次通过分解将路径分为首次到达路径和后续路径，建立三类路径的关联方程。
AI.findings: 框架可用于评估结构干预效果、推广目标中心性至多接收者场景，以及比较链接添加策略。
AI.theory_contributions: 提出了统一的路径枚举框架，扩展了生成函数在网络分析中的应用。
AI.practical_contributions: 为网络结构干预、信息网络中心性分析及链接策略优化提供了实用工具。

title: Is Gold an Inflation Hedge?
affiliations: University of Western Australia - Business School

detail.title: Is Gold an Inflation Hedge?
detail.abstract: This paper tests whether gold is an inflation hedge. The analysis reveals that gold used to be an inflation hedge in the 1970s and 1980s. Gold still preserves purchasing power but vastly exceeds inflation rates and money supply. Regression analyses clearly show that CPI changes, inflation rates, inflation rate changes, money supply changes and real interest rate changes have very low or no explanatory power on gold price movements. In contrast, we find a threshold effect with strong reactions to large inflation rates and shocks and no reaction to average or "normal" rates. Even stronger reactions of the gold price are found for 1-year and 5-year inflation expectation shocks. The results demonstrate that gold does not react to average inflation rates but to large inflation rates and shocks.

AI.tldr: 本文研究发现黄金在20世纪70年代和80年代曾是通胀对冲工具，但如今其价格变动与CPI、通胀率、货币供应量等传统指标关联性极低，仅对大幅通胀率或冲击有显著反应。
AI.research_question: 黄金是否仍是一种通胀对冲工具？
AI.motivation: 探讨黄金在现代经济环境中是否仍具备对冲通胀的功能。
AI.theoretical_framework: 通胀对冲理论、黄金价格决定因素。
AI.method: 回归分析，检验CPI、通胀率、货币供应量等对黄金价格的影响。
AI.findings: 黄金价格对平均通胀率无反应，但对大幅通胀率或冲击（尤其是1年和5年通胀预期冲击）反应强烈。
AI.theory_contributions: 揭示了黄金价格对通胀的非线性反应机制。
AI.practical_contributions: 为投资者在通胀环境下的黄金配置提供实证依据。

title: Algorithmic Empire and the New Digital Colonialism: The Legal Struggle for Technological Self-Determination in the Age of AI
affiliations: New York Law School

detail.title: Algorithmic Empire and the New Digital Colonialism: The Legal Struggle for Technological Self-Determination in the Age of AI

contentType.other: Working draft under review for publication in a peer-reviewed journal

detail.abstract:
Artificial intelligence (AI) governance is emerging as a constitutional question of sovereignty, not merely a regulatory or technical matter. This paper introduces the concept of algorithmic empire to describe how dominant AI governance models—market-led (United States), rights-based (European Union), and state-centric (China)—embed regulatory logics in technical systems with extraterritorial reach. These architectures constrain the policy autonomy of other states and risk creating a stratified order where a few jurisdictions set the rules and others comply.

Through comparative legal analysis and examination of digital trade provisions in the CPTPP and USMCA, the paper shows how early governance choices in transformative technologies can lock in structural dependencies. It proposes a framework for technological self-determination comprising constitutional recognition of AI governance authority, preservation of domestic policy space in trade agreements, and institutional capacity building.

The framework applies not only to AI but also to emerging technologies such as synthetic biology, neural connectivity, and quantum computing. The stakes are immediate: states that act now can still shape the rules; those that delay will inherit architectures designed by others.

AI.tldr: 本文提出“算法帝国”概念，探讨美国、欧盟和中国三种主导AI治理模式如何通过技术系统嵌入监管逻辑，影响他国政策自主性，并提出技术自决框架以应对新兴技术治理。
AI.research_question: 不同主导AI治理模式（市场主导、权利为本、国家中心）如何通过技术系统影响他国政策自主性？
AI.motivation: AI治理已成为主权问题，早期治理选择可能锁定结构性依赖，需提出框架以保护技术自决权。
AI.theoretical_framework: 算法帝国概念、比较法律分析、数字贸易条款研究。
AI.method: 比较法律分析，研究CPTPP和USMCA中的数字贸易条款。
AI.findings: 三种AI治理模式通过技术系统限制他国政策自主性，可能形成分层秩序。
AI.theory_contributions: 提出“算法帝国”概念及技术自决框架，扩展新兴技术治理理论。
AI.practical_contributions: 为各国提供保护政策空间和机构能力建设的实践建议，适用于AI及其他新兴技术。

title: MindStream Research Framework Concept Draft
affiliations: University of Massachusetts Boston - College of Management

detail.title: MindStream Research Framework Concept Draft
detail.abstract: The MindStream Approach is a research methodology designed for the AI era. It integrates human-AI interaction as a recognized part of idea generation, employs AI-assisted writing as a legitimate method, incorporates non-empirical consistency verification to complement the scientific methods, and embraces rapid, multi-platform dissemination, including social media, blogs, and decentralized science (DeSci) platforms, as a complement to traditional journal publication. MindStream aims to accelerate knowledge creation, democratize knowledge dissemination, and expand the epistemic toolkit available to researchers.

AI.tldr: MindStream是一种为AI时代设计的研究方法，整合人机交互、AI辅助写作、非实证一致性验证及多平台快速传播，旨在加速知识创造与民主化传播。
AI.research_question: 如何在AI时代优化研究方法以加速知识创造与传播？
AI.motivation: 传统研究方法在AI时代效率不足，需整合新技术以提升研究效能。
AI.theoretical_framework: 人机交互理论、AI辅助写作理论、非实证验证理论、知识传播理论。
AI.method: 整合人机交互、AI辅助写作、非实证验证及多平台传播。
AI.findings: MindStream能有效加速知识创造与传播，扩展研究工具库。
AI.theory_contributions: 提出AI时代研究方法的新框架，丰富了研究工具理论。
AI.practical_contributions: 为研究者提供高效工具，促进知识民主化传播。

title: Technical Change and Economic Growth as Recombinant Augmentation
affiliations: Brandeis University - International Business School

detail.title: Technical Change and Economic Growth as Recombinant Augmentation
detail.abstract: This paper interprets technical change through the lens of recombinant augmentation for which the phenomena of factor accumulation and factor augmentation are inseparable. This single assumption that households and firms accumulate offspring and raw materials only for the purpose of their augmentation transforms the representation of technical change in the steady state from the axiomatic representation of purely labor augmenting, a poor fit with empirical reality, to capital-labor invention neutral, a plausible fit. The centrality of recombinant augmentation carries deep implications for the neoclassical designation of capital as unaugmentable dollars that only accumulate and labor as workers that primarily augment.

AI.tldr: 本文通过重组增强的视角解释技术变革，将要素积累与要素增强视为不可分割的现象。这一假设将稳态中技术变革的表现从纯劳动增强的假设（与实证不符）转变为资本-劳动创新中性（更符合现实），对资本和劳动的新古典定义提出了深刻挑战。
AI.research_question: 如何通过重组增强的视角重新解释技术变革？
AI.motivation: 传统新古典理论将资本视为不可增强的积累单位，劳动则主要增强，这与实证现实不符。本文旨在提出一种更符合现实的技术变革解释框架。
AI.theoretical_framework: 重组增强理论，将要素积累与要素增强视为不可分割的过程。
AI.method: 理论建模，通过假设家庭和企业积累后代和原材料仅为了增强目的，重新表述稳态中的技术变革。
AI.findings: 技术变革在稳态中的表现从纯劳动增强转变为资本-劳动创新中性，更符合实证现实。
AI.theory_contributions: 挑战了新古典理论对资本和劳动的传统定义，提出了重组增强的理论框架。
AI.practical_contributions: 为政策制定者提供了更符合现实的技术变革分析工具，有助于更准确地评估经济增长和技术进步。

title: Impact of Boomerang CEOs on Firm Performance
affiliations: Pacific Lutheran University and University of Washington-Bothell

detail.title: Impact of Boomerang CEOs on Firm Performance
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of boomerang CEOs-executives who return to lead their previous organizations after a period of departure-on firm performance, with a particular focus on firm value and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) outcomes from 1992 to 2022. Our findings suggest while boomerang CEOs underperform relative to their non-boomerang counterparts in general, their second-term performance exhibits drastic improvements when comparing to their own first terms and their non-boomerang peers. Additionally, we find the sentiment and intensity of media coverage are predictive of the second-term improvements, suggesting media attention may create an extra layer of corporate governance for shareholders. This study contributes to the literature on corporate governance, leadership effectiveness, and sustainability by highlighting the unique role boomerang CEOs play in fostering ESG advancements.

AI.tldr: 研究探讨了“回旋镖CEO”（即离职后重返原公司领导层的CEO）对公司绩效的影响，重点关注1992年至2022年间公司价值和ESG表现。结果显示，尽管回旋镖CEO整体表现不如非回旋镖CEO，但其第二任期表现显著优于第一任期及非回旋镖CEO。媒体情绪和报道强度能预测第二任期改进，表明媒体关注可能为股东提供额外公司治理层。
AI.research_question: 回旋镖CEO对公司绩效（尤其是公司价值和ESG表现）有何影响？
AI.motivation: 探讨回旋镖CEO对公司治理、领导效能和可持续发展的独特作用。
AI.theoretical_framework: 公司治理理论、领导效能理论、可持续发展理论。
AI.method: 1992年至2022年的数据分析，比较回旋镖CEO与非回旋镖CEO的表现。
AI.findings: 回旋镖CEO整体表现较差，但第二任期显著改善；媒体关注能预测改进。
AI.theory_contributions: 丰富了公司治理和领导效能理论，强调回旋镖CEO在ESG进步中的作用。
AI.practical_contributions: 为股东和公司提供关于回旋镖CEO潜在价值的见解，媒体可作为治理工具。

title: Biodiversity Abundance Markers and Business Activity in New Zealand: Evidence from a Spatial Analysis
affiliations: University of California, Davis - Graduate School of Management and Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka - School of Accounting and Commercial Law

detail.title: Biodiversity Abundance Markers and Business Activity in New Zealand: Evidence from a Spatial Analysis
detail.abstract: Tracking biodiversity's impact on business activity presents a significant challenge for managers, investors, and policymakers. Without a deeper analysis, the financial opportunities and risks posed by a changing natural environment may not be adequately identified. One shortcoming of the empirical research so far is its failure to recognize that a firm's association with nature is highly spatially specific. Biodiversity can vary significantly across the different locations where businesses operate. Understanding how nature influences business activity also requires knowledge of the biological and physical phenomena shaping the natural world. We address these issues by leveraging two unique aspects of the New Zealand landscape: (i) the availability of granular biodiversity markers from rich sources of data and (ii) monthly sales and employment data collected by the government on businesses operating in the same location as the biodiversity markers. By matching these datasets, we can examine whether and how various science-based biodiversity markers associate with business output. We measure biodiversity based on a location's biodiversity abundance (BDA) markers. We find that businesses operating in areas with favorable BDAs-with better land use, lower population density, fewer invasive pests, and reduced drought probability-exhibit higher productivity, as measured by sales and gross profit per business unit. We also find higher output per business unit in areas with more Indigenous knowledge, another favorable BDA marker. Overall, our results align with the theory that the business productivity of a land area varies positively with its natural capital, as proxied by a higher level of biodiversity abundance.

AI.tldr: 研究通过新西兰的独特数据，探讨了生物多样性对企业生产力的影响，发现有利的生物多样性指标（如土地利用、人口密度等）与企业生产力正相关。
AI.research_question: 生物多样性如何影响企业生产力？
AI.motivation: 当前研究未能充分识别生物多样性对企业活动的财务机会与风险，且忽视了其空间特异性。
AI.theoretical_framework: 自然资本理论，认为生物多样性是企业生产力的重要因素。
AI.method: 利用新西兰的精细生物多样性数据与政府提供的企业销售和就业数据匹配分析。
AI.findings: 有利的生物多样性指标（如土地利用、人口密度等）与企业生产力（销售和毛利）正相关。
AI.theory_contributions: 验证了自然资本理论，强调了生物多样性对企业生产力的重要性。
AI.practical_contributions: 为管理者、投资者和政策制定者提供了识别生物多样性对企业活动影响的工具。

title: Influence by Omission: The IMF's Lending Capacity and Central Bank Design
affiliations: University of Essex - Department of Government and University of Queensland

detail.title: Influence by Omission: The IMF's Lending Capacity and Central Bank Design
detail.abstract: A large literature explores how loan conditionalities and policy recommendations embedded in International Monetary Fund lending programs influence country behavior and policy choices. We argue that the IMF's influence extends beyond these intentional efforts. This paper shows that the growth in the IMF's lending capacity has failed to keep pace with financial globalization, and that this has incentivized emerging and developing economies to strengthen their domestic institutions for financial stability, particularly, their central bank's capabilities to act as a lender of last resort. We conceptualize this as influence by omission, whereby the IMF shapes behavior not through direct engagement but through its declining ability to serve as an effective financial backstop. Using original data coding central bank lender of last resort powers for 60 developing countries between 1994 and 2020, we find that countries with relatively limited access to IMF resources are significantly more likely to strengthen their central banks' lender of last resort authority. This finding is robust across a range of model specifications, instrumental variable analyses, and dynamic estimations. An event study of countries' response to the Covid shock reveals that countries with stronger lending of last resort capabilities were much more likely to manage the crisis without drawing on IMF resources. Importantly, this effect is specific to lender of last resort powers and does not extend to other aspects of central bank governance such as independence or transparency, suggesting that distinct international and domestic incentives shape different reform trajectories.

AI.tldr: 本文探讨了国际货币基金组织（IMF）贷款能力增长未能跟上金融全球化的步伐，导致新兴和发展中经济体加强国内金融稳定机构（尤其是央行作为最后贷款人的能力）的现象。作者将这种影响称为“遗漏影响”，并通过实证分析验证了IMF资源有限的国家更可能加强央行最后贷款人权力。
AI.research_question: IMF贷款能力增长未能跟上金融全球化步伐如何影响新兴和发展中经济体加强国内金融稳定机构（尤其是央行最后贷款人能力）？
AI.motivation: 现有文献主要关注IMF贷款条件性和政策建议对国家的直接影响，而忽略了其间接影响。本文旨在填补这一空白，探讨IMF通过其能力不足对国内政策的间接塑造作用。
AI.theoretical_framework: 本文提出了“遗漏影响”的概念，即IMF通过其能力不足间接影响国家行为，而非直接干预。
AI.method: 使用1994年至2020年60个发展中国家的原始数据，编码央行最后贷款人权力，并进行多种模型分析（包括工具变量分析和动态估计）。
AI.findings: IMF资源有限的国家更可能加强央行最后贷款人权力；在新冠疫情期间，具备更强最后贷款人能力的国家更少依赖IMF资源。
AI.theory_contributions: 提出了“遗漏影响”概念，扩展了IMF影响力的理论框架。
AI.practical_contributions: 为新兴和发展中经济体在金融全球化背景下加强国内金融稳定机构提供了政策启示。

title: Informed Trading and the Fossil Fuel Industry's Influence Over Un Climate Meetings
affiliations: Macquarie University, Macquarie Business School, Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT University) - School of Economics, Finance and Marketing, affiliation not provided to SSRN, The University of Technology Sydney and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Informed Trading and the Fossil Fuel Industry's Influence Over Un Climate Meetings
detail.abstract: This study develops a novel methodology to estimate the probability of informed trading around United Nations COP climate meetings. Analyzing options market data from 87 U.S.-listed fossil fuel firms between 2006 and 2023, we find that informed trading rises significantly during the [–9, 9] day window. This activity generated abnormal returns of 22.46%, or up to $32.895 billion in profit for informed traders over the relevant period. Given the fossil fuel industry’s substantial presence at COP meetings, our findings suggest that these events offer not only policy signals but also informational advantages to select market participants.

AI.tldr: 本研究开发了一种新方法，用于估计联合国COP气候会议期间知情交易的概率。通过分析2006年至2023年间87家美国上市化石燃料公司的期权市场数据，发现知情交易在会议前后9天内显著增加，产生了22.46%的异常收益，或高达328.95亿美元的利润。
AI.research_question: 联合国COP气候会议期间，化石燃料行业是否存在显著的知情交易行为？
AI.motivation: 化石燃料行业在COP会议中具有重要影响力，研究其市场行为有助于揭示政策信号与市场信息优势的关系。

AI.method: 分析87家美国上市化石燃料公司2006-2023年的期权市场数据，采用事件窗口法。
AI.findings: 会议前后9天内知情交易显著增加，产生22.46%的异常收益或328.95亿美元利润。
AI.theory_contributions: 扩展了知情交易理论在气候政策事件中的应用。

title: Fear and Risk Perception: Understanding Physicians' Dynamic Responses to Malpractice Lawsuits
affiliations: University of Pennsylvania - Department of Economics, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen and Indiana University - Kelley School of Business - Department of Business Economics & Public Policy

detail.title: Fear and Risk Perception: Understanding Physicians' Dynamic Responses to Malpractice Lawsuits

declarations.funderStatement: Li gratefully acknowledges the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 72403216 and 72192804), the Guangdong Basic and Applied Basic Research Foundation (No. 2022B1515120060), and the Research Fund of the School of Management and Economics, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, for financial support.

detail.abstract:
This paper investigates how physicians adjust their clinical decision-making following medical malpractice lawsuits and how these responses are driven by mental rather than financial costs, and do not align with rational expectations. We combine a comprehensive health insurance claim database from a Chinese city with the universe of malpractice lawsuits to study changes in physician behavior and patient outcomes. We find that physicians respond to lawsuits by practicing more conservatively, rejecting high-risk patients, reducing surgery rates, and increasing the use of diagnostic tests and traditional Chinese medicine. These changes are associated with worse patient outcomes, consistent with defensive medicine. The effects are not limited to the directly involved departments but spill over to other departments within the same hospital. In addition, the changes are short-lived, with physicians reverting to their pre-lawsuit treatment patterns in eight weeks. We provide evidence that such responses are likely driven by mental cost (including fear) and deviate from rational expectations. First, physicians in hospitals with more and less frequent lawsuits exhibit similar responses to a new lawsuit; moreover, they respond similarly to winning and losing cases. Second, physicians’ reactions to a patient’s death vary depending on the recency of a salient lawsuit. Lastly, physician responses are especially strong following criminal violence against physicians, which is emotionally and psychologically salient.

AI.tldr: 本文研究了医生在医疗事故诉讼后如何调整临床决策，发现其行为变化主要由心理成本（如恐惧）而非财务成本驱动，且偏离理性预期。
AI.research_question: 医生在医疗事故诉讼后如何调整临床决策？这些调整是否由心理成本驱动？
AI.motivation: 探讨医疗事故诉讼对医生行为的影响，揭示其背后的心理机制。
AI.theoretical_framework: 行为经济学、心理成本理论、防御性医疗理论。

detail.title: Transitioning to a Renewable Future – a Critical Analysis of New York State Energy Trends Through Machine Learning Models
detail.abstract: Clean energy technologies, encompassing renewable resources like solar, wind, and hydropower, are essential in the global effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and combat climate change. As the globe prepares to transition away from fossil fuels, understanding the factors and parameters influencing the penetration of clean energy into existing energy markets has become a critical step. Controversies surrounding the environmental impacts of renewable technologies, variability in market structures, and economic pressures on clean energy companies can complicate this transition. Thus, resources must be focused in the right areas to ensure the growing demand for sustainable energy solutions is being met adequately. In this study, we employ a suite of machine learning models—including Linear Regression, Random Forest Regression, Gradient Boosting Regression, AdaBoost Regression, and XGBoost Regression—to analyze geographic and policy-driven parameters influencing clean energy adoption across New York State. Strategic investments in high-potential parameters, alongside targeted policy interventions and technological advancements, can maximize the impact of clean energy initiatives while ensuring long-term sustainability and economic viability. Key parameters analyzed include solar and wind potential, average energy prices, subsidy amounts, grid capacity, public awareness, renewable and fossil energy market shares, and policy support indices. Despite challenges such as market variability and infrastructure limitations, this research offers a data-driven blueprint to bridge demand-supply gaps and guide policymaking, making sure energy investments are focused in the right areas, fostering a sustainable energy future.

detail.title: Green Electricity, Labeling and Competition in the French Retail Electricity Market
detail.abstract: With growing environmental concerns, recent empirical studies have shown that consumers are willing to pay more for eco-friendly products, such as those certified by an eco-label or as green electricity. In this context, the aim of this paper is twofold. Firstly, we examine whether renewable electricity retailing is a profitable strategy for firms, in the presence of what we call concerned and responsible consumers, with regard to environmental issues only. Secondly, we study whether labeling green electricity products in a more sustainable approach, considering not only the environmental but also the economic and social concerns of consumers, could enhance the greening dynamic observed in the market. Through a horizontal product differentiation model, we show that when accounting for consumers' concern for the provision of public goods at the environmental level, differentiation represents the best strategy for electricity retailers at the equilibrium. Furthermore, when including the label in the analysis, the greening of the market would depend on the degree of consumers' concern towards the economic and social aspects related to the purchase of a labeled green electricity product. Concerning social welfare, we show that having both firms sell green electricity would be socially optimal, and that accounting for the three dimensions of sustainable development through the label improves consumers' surplus and social welfare.

detail.title: Whether It's Weather or Climate: Temperature and Individual Deprivation in Sub-Saharan Africa
detail.abstract: We use a large-scale, geo-referenced household survey spanning 28 African countries over 16 years to investigate the link between temperatures and individual living standards in one of the world’s most climate-vulnerable regions. We evaluate both the short-term response to temperature (shocks) and the long-term equilibrium effects of climate change by matching daily, bi-monthly, monthly, yearly and long-term average temperature data to 168,585 individuals across 14,186 unique survey locales. Our results consistently reveal a statistically robust and negative association between elevated temperatures and individual deprivation which is measured as insufficient access to food, water, healthcare, and income, across both short- and long-term time horizons. However, the quantitative magnitude of these effects is very modest for short-term temperatures often statistically indistinguishable from zero. Importantly, we find that local infrastructural endowments significantly moderate temperature-related impacts, suggesting that investments in basic infrastructure can meaningfully buffer individuals from the adverse effects of both short- and long-term warming.

title: The Political Economy of Manumission Restrictions Evidence from Late Antebellum Southern Legislatures

detail.title: The Political Economy of Manumission Restrictions Evidence from Late Antebellum Southern Legislatures
detail.abstract: This paper examines the political economy of manumission restrictions in the late Antebellum U.S. South, focusing on the role of large-scale slaveholding interests. We investigate the legislative voting records from four states (Alabama, Kentucky, Maryland, and Tennessee) using district-level economic and demographic data, and legislator-level information from the US Censuses for 1830 and 1850. We find that representatives from regions where large-scale slaveholding was prevalent, as well as legislators who were large slaveholders themselves, were significantly more likely to support legislation restricting manumission. These findings are consistent with a model of legislators’ voting behavior that treats manumission as an effective tool to motivate labor for only some, and detrimental to the interests of other, slaveholders. By limiting manumission, these policies safeguarded the ability of large-scale slaveholders like plantation owners to rely on coercion to motivate their enslaved workers. Our findings suggest that restrictive manumission laws were not purely ideological but were rooted in the concentrated economic interests of Southern elites, highlighting the broader relationship between wealth, political power, and the institutional entrenchment of slavery.

detail.title: Estimating the Health and Economic Impacts of Supporting Individuals with Physical and Mental Health Conditions into Employment Using ‘IPS-MOD’ - A New Cost-Benefit Analysis Tool for England

declarations.declarationOfInterest: We declare that we have no conflicts of interest.
declarations.funderStatement: This project is funded by the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR) (Project Ref 202996).

detail.abstract:
Background: Individual Placement and Support (IPS) is an employment support programme which has successfully supported individuals with severe mental illness into employment. Recent trials in the UK have applied this intervention to individuals with low-to-moderate mental health (MH) and musculoskeletal conditions (MSK). This study evaluates the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of providing IPS to individuals with low to moderate MH and/or MSK conditions. To do this, we use a new open source modelling tool, the IPS cost-benefit and outcomes MODel (IPS-MOD). 

Methods: IPS-MOD uses a Markov structure and simulates transitions between employment and non-employment states in both intervention and business-as-usual (BAU) scenarios. Incorporating data from trial evidence, national survey datasets and tax-benefit micro-simulation. Estimated outcomes are employment rates, Quality-Adjusted Life Years (QALYs), government expenditures, and net earnings over a five-year horizon. Sensitivity analyses assess the robustness of the benefit-cost ratios for different service costs and effectiveness levels. 

Findings: The estimated benefit-cost ratio from a societal perspective for those with MSK showed that every £1 spent on IPS services returned £1.13 by the end of Year 1 and £5.76 by the end of Year 5. The intervention is estimated to, by year 5, improve employment rates by a 5.87% relative increase and increase QALYs by 0.139 per person. This is alongside savings of £1,009.92 in social security payments and £124.59 in health service resource use per person by year 5. Comparable patterns of effectiveness and cost-effectiveness were observed across all health conditions. Sensitivity analysis confirmed the robustness of these results. 

Interpretation: IPS for people with MH, MSK or MSK+MH is estimated to have a positive economic return-on-investment. Expanding IPS services to these groups, could provide substantial long-term financial and social returns. The IPS-MOD tool can be customised to different localities and is able to be used to support future policy decisions aimed at reducing work-related health disparities. Our new IPS-MOD evidence and tool are an important policy contribution for regional and local policy stakeholders especially as they begin to commission, manage and monitor the new DWP funded £1bn Connect to Work programme across England and Wales.

title: Gaming the Test? Window-Dressing and Portfolio Similarity Around the Eu-Wide Stress Tests
affiliations: Scuola Superiore Sant’Anna, European Central Bank (ECB) and European Central Bank (ECB)

detail.title: Gaming the Test? Window-Dressing and Portfolio Similarity Around the Eu-Wide Stress Tests
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of supervisory stress testing on banks’ behaviors and their systemic risk implications. Utilizing confidential supervisory data from the European Banking Authority’s EU-wide stress tests in 2021 and 2023, we employ a difference-in-differences framework to analyze how these exercises influence portfolio management decisions among European banks. This methodology allows us to compare stress-tested banks with similar non-tested institutions before and after the stress test events, isolating the effects specifically associated with the EU-wide assessments. Our findings reveal significant patterns of anticipatory behavior, with banks strategically window-dressing their capital ratios before stress tests begin. This behavior is particularly pronounced among institutions that subsequently receive the lowest scores in terms of capital depletion. We document that these anticipatory adjustments lead to decreased portfolio similarity across banks, an effect that persists after the stress tests and remains consistent across different similarity measures. Importantly, such a decrease in similarity does not spin off into more granular business model or country clusters, thus limiting potential systemic risk through portfolio synchronization. Our results, while considering how financial institutions incorporate stress test considerations into their strategic decision-making, highlight the dual role of stress tests in enhancing individual bank resilience and reducing systemic vulnerabilities. These findings contribute to the ongoing debate on effective banking supervision and the design of regulatory stress testing frameworks.

detail.abstract: Return prediction with Random Fourier Features (RFF)-a very large number, P , of nonlinear transformations of a small number, K, of predictor variables-has become popular recently. Surprisingly, this approach appears to yield a successful out-of-sample stock market index timing strategy even when trained in rolling windows as small as T = 12 months with P in the thousands. However, when P >> T , the RFF-based forecast becomes a weighted average of the T training sample returns, with weights determined by the similarity between the predictor vectors in the training data and the current predictor vector. In short training windows, similarity primarily reflects temporal proximity, so the forecast reduces to a recency-weighted average of the T return observations in the training data-essentially a momentum strategy. Moreover, because similarity declines with predictor volatility, the result is a volatility-timed momentum strategy. The strong performance of the RFF-based strategy thus stems not from its ability to extract predictive signals from the training data, but from the fact that a volatility-timed momentum strategy happened to perform well in historical data. This point becomes clear when applying the same method to artificial data in which returns exhibit reversals rather than momentum: the RFF approach still constructs the same volatility-timed momentum strategy, which then performs poorly.

detail.abstract: I describe nine implications of the interconnectedness of fiscal and monetary policy that surface in Heterogeneous Agent New Keynesian (HANK) models. Not all are unique to HANK models. (i) Long run fiscal changes force monetary adjustments. (ii) Sustainable permanent deficits are feasible. (iii) Monetary policy leaves fiscal footprints, even with passive fiscal policy. (iv) Fewer controversies around active fiscal policy. (v) Equilibria are unique under a wider class of fiscal and monetary rules. (vi) With short-term debt, raising nominal rates without a fiscal contraction raises inflation. (vii) Unfunded fiscal stimulus is more inflationary. (viii) Even fully funded fiscal stimulus is inflationary. (ix) Fiscal transfers can substitute for monetary policy in the aggregate.

detail.abstract: While economic approaches to contract law often presume that private ordering yields efficient outcomes and concentrates on crafting optimal remedies to support voluntary exchange and promise-keeping, regulatory contract law starts from a different perspective, recognizing that the core assumptions of the standard economic paradigm break down when contracts produce externalities, are built around information asymmetries, or exacerbate collective-action problems. This chapter discusses the market-failure rationale for regulatory contract law, positioning it within the broader architecture of public law. Our analysis identifies when and how regulatory intervention can enhance welfare and preserve the integrity of contractual dealings. This framework offers an efficiency-based economic justification for regulatory contract law grounded on the correction of market failures.

detail.abstract: As new education technology applications emerge, teachers and school leaders must decide which ones to endorse. What influences these decisions? This study examines how information about two aspects of ed tech apps-efficacy and popularity-affects educators' choices to adopt them. We present causal estimates from two experiments: a within-subject survey of 1,104 teachers (pre-K through grade 4) and a between-subjects experiment with 154 school leaders. In the first experiment, providing teachers with a cue about strong research evidence increased their likelihood of recommending a math learning app by 0.24 SD (compared to a no-cue control), while a peer-popularity cue raised it by 0.21 SD; using both cues together led to a 0.30 SD increase. In the second experiment, showing school leaders an informational video about a math app's popularity and research evidence did not significantly increase their likelihood of recommending the app or their willingness to pay for it.

detail.title: How to Tax Environmentally Detrimental Status Goods?
detail.abstract: In this paper, we study a theoretical model of a car market with status goods and environmental externalities, and endogenous technology choice. We study first-best taxation with individual status tax rates, we derive a second-best tax rule for a uniform status tax combined with an emission tax, and a third-best tax rule with an emission tax only. Using numerical simulations, we find that the welfare difference between first- and second-best taxation is small, while the difference between second- and third-best taxation is substantial. Using results from a related paper, we propose a "status" tax at the level of 16 Euro per horse power (PS).

detail.abstract: We conducted a randomized controlled trial to compare the effectiveness of three interventions in promoting a societally valuable habit: in-house waste sorting. Nearly 1,100 households living in apartment buildings in downtown Amsterdam were assigned to either a neoclassical treatment using extrinsic incentives or one of two behavioral treatments aimed at fostering intrinsic motivation or reciprocity. The extrinsic and reciprocity-based interventions both led to immediate but short-lived improvements, primarily via intensification of sorting by households already engaged in the activity. In contrast, the intrinsic motivation treatment generated equally strong but more persistent effects and was particularly effective at encouraging non-sorting households to start sorting. These findings highlight the key role of intrinsic motivation in establishing and sustaining prosocial habits.

title: Unwillingly Informed: The Prosocial Impact of Third-Party Informers
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of California, Merced - Department of Economics, University of Oslo - Department of Economics and University of Oslo - Department of Economics

detail.title: Unwillingly Informed: The Prosocial Impact of Third-Party Informers
detail.abstract: While people often avoid learning about negative social and environmental consequences of their actions in order to behave selfishly, many social situations involve another person who is in a position to impose this information. How does the presence of a potential informer affect information, behavior, and welfare in social decisions with moral wiggle-room? We introduce a third-party informer into the moral wiggle-room game. Almost half of the dictators tried to avoid information only to have it imposed upon them by the informer. These unwillingly-informed dictators frequently revised their behavior to benefit the recipient, even at their own expense. Given an opportunity to reward informers, most dictators chose to do so, but those who had bad news thrust upon them by the informer were more likely to withhold the reward. Interestingly, a subtle change in the choice interface—separating the dictator’s ignorance and allocation choices in two separate screens—caused a substantial reduction in the share of dictators choosing ignorance.

AI.tldr: 本文探讨了在存在潜在信息提供者的社会决策中，信息、行为和福利如何受到影响。研究发现，近半数的独裁者试图避免负面信息，但信息提供者会强制提供这些信息，导致独裁者行为改变。此外，选择界面的微小变化显著减少了独裁者选择无知的比例。

detail.abstract: In the era of big data, service quality evaluation using online reviews has become a popular topic. However, very few studies focus simultaneously on service quality evaluation and service improvement. In this study, a research framework for service quality evaluation and service improvement is proposed, sentiment analysis is used to extract the temporal scores of the service attributes of each subdimension of the service quality model from online reviews, and a long short-term memory network is used to predict the scores for the service quality provider. Furthermore, a long short-term memory network-based sensitivity analysis, in conjunction with improvement costs, is used to rank the subdimensions in the service quality model. Then, service improvement strategies are determined according to the rankings of the service attributes. Hotels' online reviews were used to investigate the effectiveness of the proposed framework. A series of service improvement strategies for the specific service attributes are provided.

title: Democratizing Content Creation: Impacts of Generative AI on Content Competition and Profitability of Human Creators
affiliations: Hong Kong University of Science & Technology (HKUST) - Department of Information & Systems Management, The University of Texas at Dallas, Jindal School of Management and University of North Texas

detail.title: Democratizing Content Creation: Impacts of Generative AI on Content Competition and Profitability of Human Creators
detail.abstract: Generative AI is significantly reshaping the creative industries by democratizing content creation while simultaneously raising concerns regarding content competition and profitability of human creators. We develop a game-theoretic model to examine the economic impact of generative AI, focusing on its influence on human creators' strategic decisions regarding content differentiation and pricing. We find that AI-generated content is sustainable only when both generative AI's quality and creative capabilities are not too low. As these capabilities improve, AI-generated content increasingly captures demand for human-created content, prompting human creators to differentiate themselves to mitigate competition. However, overall content diversity increases only when generative AI's creative capability is high enough. Our analysis further reveals that generative AI's quality and creative capabilities exert opposing effects on human creators' profitability: higher creativity enhances differentiation and reduces price competition, while higher quality increases substitutability between AI and human-generated content and intensifies competition. When generative AI exhibits high creativity but low quality, human creators may benefit from its presence due to improved consumer targeting and reduced competition. Finally, our results show that, although AI-generated content can expand content variety, improve consumer matching, and lower human creators' creative costs through intensified competition, it enhances overall social welfare and consumer surplus only when its quality is sufficiently high. These findings offer practical guidance for platform designers and policymakers on how to balance AI deployment with incentives for human creativity in content ecosystems.

detail.abstract: The manual process of student clearance during graduation in many academic institutions has proven to be inefficient, error-prone, and time-consuming. Students often encounter challenges such as long queues, delays in form processing, the unavailability of key staff members, repeated visits to administrative offices, and the loss of important documents. These issues frequently result in delayed graduation and disrupted participation in national service or further academic pursuits. To address these shortcomings, this project proposes the development of an Online Student Clearance System designed to streamline and automate the clearance process. The system aims to eliminate the inefficiencies inherent in manual procedures by providing a reliable, accessible, and efficient digital platform. It enables students to initiate and complete their clearance remotely, reducing the need for physical presence and administrative overhead. The system is developed using the Model-View-Controller (MVC) architectural pattern and implemented with HTML for the user interface and Visual Studio as the integrated development environment, with a local database server for data management. This web-based solution is intended to significantly improve the speed, accuracy, and convenience of the clearance process for both students and administrative staff.

detail.abstract: This paper quantifies the size of the main industrial policy instruments in China and estimates their impact on domestic factor misallocation and aggregate productivity. The quantification of industrial policy instruments leverages data from financial reports of listed firms and the land registry. The equivalent fiscal cost of industrial policy through cash subsidies, tax benefits, subsidized credit, and subsidized land for favored sectors (including both private and state-owned firms) is estimated at about 4 percent of GDP per year, with a growing share of tax benefits over time. Next, the paper uses a structural model to estimate the relationship between industrial policies and factor misallocation for a broad sample of firms. Various industrial policy instruments are found to affect factor allocations in different ways—subsidies tend to lead to excess production, while trade and regulatory barriers limit production. Overall, factor misallocation from industrial policies is estimated to reduce domestic aggregate TFP by about 1.2 percent. The results resonate with IMF policy recommendations for China to scale back industrial policy and increase its transparency.

detail.abstract: Medium-term growth prospects of Caribbean countries have weakened in recent years. We examine these trends by providing new estimates of potential GDP growth for the region. Our findings reveal a broad-based decline over time, driven by declining contributions from human capital and total factor productivity. Linking these factors to firm-level data, we identify significant scope for aggregate productivity gains through the efficient reallocation of resources between firms and the removal of firm-level structural obstacles. Addressing issues such as the cost and access to finance, workforce education, tax administration, and business licensing and permits are associated with higher aggregate welfare.

detail.abstract: The U.S. economy has undergone profound structural transformations in recent decades. This descriptive study analyzes tradable and nontradable sectoral trends, with our findings demonstrating that the share of tradable sector employment and, within it, manufacturing employment, leveled off in the decade following the GFC after declining for several decades. Still, by 2023, the nontradable sector accounted for a large majority of employment and real value added. At the same time, the tradable sector exhibited robust productivity growth of nearly 3 percent, juxtaposed against far lower 0.7 percent growth in nontradable sectors. This marked divergence raises concerns regarding inequality and the sustainability of economic growth.

detail.abstract: This paper examines the role of cost accounting in public financial management, focusing on budget credibility, performance-based budgeting, public procurement, and corruption detection. Despite demonstrated benefits, cost accounting remains underutilized in the public sector due to implementation constraints. The working paper proposes the adoption of automated cost accounting systems to streamline processes, reduce operational costs, and support complex data analyses. It further emphasizes the need for interoperability between government financial systems and administrative records to enhance the granularity of costing indicators. The paper also explores machine learning as a method to support budgetary decision-making with cost accounting data.

title: Macroeconomic and Fiscal Consequences of Quantitative Easing

detail.title: Macroeconomic and Fiscal Consequences of Quantitative Easing

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Quantitative easing (QE) has been criticized for helping fuel the post-COVID inflation boom and causing large central bank losses. In this paper, we argue that QE should be evaluated mainly on its ability to achieve core macro-objectives as well for its effects on the consolidated fiscal position of the government and central bank, although central bank losses can matter to the extent that they may weaken central bank credibility. Using a DSGE model with segmented asset markets, we show how QE can provide a sizeable boost to output and inflation in a deep liquidity trap and can reduce public debt substantially. This contrasts to the rise in public debt that occurs under fiscal expansion and makes QE an attractive tool in a high debt environment.  There is more reason for caution in using QE in a “shallow" liquidity trap in which the notional interest rate is only slightly negative: QE runs more risk of causing the economy to overheat, especially if forward guidance has a strong element of commitment, and is more likely to generate sizeable central bank losses. Some refinements in strategy, including the use of escape clauses, can help mitigate overheating risks.
